item.title: It’s Monday
item.description: A poem that, in my head, it’s jazz Photo taken by Lucia Ferro It’s Monday, and you’re already done. It’s Monday, and you’ve had enough. Four days seem too much, but you don’t know what would they hide. A shiny cold day or a pleasant lunch. It’s Monday, what a bad start. You’ve judged the week before you’ve tried to look for moments that make worthy lifes. They turn dark clouds

item.title: World Anxiety
item.description: A new perspective on an old concept The Netherlands. Photo taken by Lucía Ferro. The world feels big. Big like the desert when you just leave the oasis. Chaos burns full of entropy like the skin of my feet stepping on boiling sand bathed with dry heat. I cannot bare any more the details of this reality. I want to be drowsy and bored with some soothing fantasy. But this strong and wild and feverish curiosity

item.title: The Weak In The Sky
item.description: A poem about compassion Switzerland, photo taken by the author We think we are brilliant when we see others’ wrong side. We treat them rough; we ignore their shine. As if life wasn’t hard enough, we forget to note when they’re right. And that’s what we’ve become: Judges of the weak and fragile. We feel strong and tough. We forget our own troubled times without which we wouldn’t have seen the light.

item.description: A poem to patience in friendship Photo by Lucía Ferro Don’t you dare break into my soul looking for gems that can be sold to warm yourself up when it’s cold and forget about me when you find a clear road. item.title: Time to spare
item.description: A poem fueled with indignation Photo by Andrik Langfield on Unsplash I feel judged by the lot when I am trying to be more. More of myself. More of the woman I left behind when I was surviving, and I didn’t have time for thriving. But now I do. I revise my behaviour and my childhood and I find terrible things, but sometimes, I also find it. My authenticity. So why do they judge me?

item.title: You grew just like them
item.description: A poem with disappointment Photo by Enrico Da Prato on Unsplash You, with me, were there when the monsters yelled. Under the sheets hiding from darkness and scared, you and I, trembling through a nightmare. You talked about dreams so I would forget we were children living in hell. item.title: Awakening to breath
item.description: The Dark Night Of The Soul Eindhoven by Lucía Ferro I see myself over and over at the bottom of a well. The water keeps raising. My chest keeps aching. I take my last breath and the water covers my head. But the air I exhale creates a bubble of pain. And I feed on the pain, becoming the fuel of my internal duel. Oh, the fight it elevates me high

item.title: One day at a time
item.description: A poem about the past Photo: Simple wild life by Lucía Ferro I woke up tired from last night. The breakfast doesn’t go down through my irritated gut. I am nauseous. I throw up, ready for the bus to pick me up. I sit alone. I don’t want to chat. I want to sleep but I have things to think about. Today the bully will strike, and no one will hear me shout,
